title: Jekyll Documentation Redesign
description:
# Jekyll Documentation Redesign

Modernize the Barrister2 documentation site with a clean, Stripe/Vercel-inspired aesthetic using the Just the Docs theme.

## Goal

Transform the current basic Jekyll documentation into a modern, polished developer documentation site with:
- "Just the Docs" theme with sidebar navigation
- Purple/indigo color scheme (#6366f1 primary)
- Improved typography (Inter font, better hierarchy)
- Redesigned homepage with hero section
- Enhanced code blocks with copy functionality
- Mobile-responsive design
- Lighthouse 90+ performance score

## Architecture

Three-column layout:
- Left sidebar with hierarchical navigation and search
- Center content area (700px optimal width)
- Right "On this page" table of contents (sticky on desktop)

## Tech Stack

- Jekyll (static site generator)
- Just the Docs theme
- SCSS for customization
- JavaScript for interactive elements (copy buttons, search)

## Phases

1. **Setup & Configuration** - Add theme, configure Jekyll, create navigation structure
2. **Custom Styling** - Colors, typography, code blocks, buttons, callouts
3. **Layout & Components** - Homepage, search, copy buttons, TOC
4. **Content Migration** - Reorganize all content, add front matter
5. **Custom Components** - Breadcrumbs, callouts, edit links
6. **Responsive Design & Polish** - Mobile/tablet testing, performance, accessibility
7. **Testing & Documentation** - Link validation, search testing, guides
8. **Deployment** - Build, deploy, smoke test

## Source Documents

- Plan: docs/plans/2026-01-13-jekyll-docs-redesign-plan.md
- Design: docs/plans/2026-01-13-jekyll-docs-redesign-design.md
close_reason: Epic complete - All 33 tasks executed and verified: Setup & Configuration, Custom Styling, Layout & Components, Content Migration, Custom Components, Responsive Design (mobile/tablet), Cross-browser compatibility, Performance optimization, WCAG AA accessibility, Link validation, Search functionality, Theming guide, Developer documentation

title: Add Just the Docs Theme to Gemfile

Add the Just the Docs Jekyll theme to the documentation site.

- No syntax errors in Gemfile

title: Barrister2 Documentation Site
description:
# Barrister2 Documentation Site

Comprehensive documentation site for Barrister2 hosted on GitHub Pages with Jekyll and Lunr.js search.

## Overview

Create complete documentation including:
- Installation guide (4 methods)
- E-commerce checkout example IDL
- Language-specific quickstarts for all 5 supported languages (Go, Java, Python, TypeScript, C#)
- IDL reference guide (syntax, types, validation)
- Working code examples with automated testing
- GitHub Actions deployment pipeline

## Tech Stack

- **Jekyll 4.x** - Static site generator (GitHub Pages native)
- **Lunr.js** - Client-side search
- **GitHub Pages** - Hosting via `gh-pages` branch
- **GitHub Actions** - CI/CD pipeline

## Quickstart Example: E-Commerce Checkout

The example demonstrates:
- 3 interfaces: CatalogService, CartService, OrderService
- 5 enums/structs: Product, Cart, Order, Address, PaymentMethod
- Custom error codes (1001-1005): cart_not_found, cart_empty, payment_failed, out_of_stock, invalid_address

## Success Criteria

1. Documentation site builds locally with `bundle exec jekyll serve`
2. All code examples run successfully via test scripts
3. Quickstart guides are complete and copy-pasteable
4. Search works via Lunr.js
5. Site deploys to GitHub Pages via GitHub Actions
6. CI tests all examples and prevents broken docs
7. All 5 supported languages have complete quickstarts

---

**Source:** Implementation plan docs/plans/2026-01-13-documentation-plan.md
**Design:** docs/plans/2026-01-13-documentation-design.md

title: Create Jekyll site structure
description:
# Create Jekyll site structure Create the foundational Jekyll site files and configuration. ## Files to create 1. **`docs/_config.yml`** - Jekyll configuration: ```yaml title: Barrister2 RPC description: IDL-based JSON-RPC code generation lang: en baseurl: /barrister2 markdown: kramdown highlighter: rouge plugins: - jekyll-seo-tag - jekyll-sitemap exclude: - Gemfile - Gemfile.lock - node_modules - vendor/bundle collections: pages: output: true permalink: /:path/ ``` 2. **`docs/_layouts/default.html`** - Main layout: ```html {{ site.title }} | {{ page.title }} {% include header.html %}
{{ content }}
{% include footer.html %} ``` 3. **`docs/_includes/header.html`** - Site header with basic navigation: ```html

{{ site.title }}

  • Get Started
  • IDL Guide
  • Languages
``` 4. **`docs/_includes/footer.html`** - Site footer: ```html

© 2024 Barrister2. Built with Jekyll.

``` 5. **`docs/index.md`** - Landing page with project overview 6. **`docs/assets/css/styles.css`** - Basic styling 7. **`docs/Gemfile`** - Ruby dependencies: ```ruby source "https://rubygems.org" gem "jekyll", "~> 4.3" gem "jekyll-seo-tag" gem "jekyll-sitemap" ``` ## Verification Run `bundle exec jekyll serve` in `/docs` directory - site should serve at http://localhost:4000 ## Expected outcome - Jekyll site builds without errors - Basic navigation works - Landing page displays
design:
## Design Context

**Goal:** Create foundational Jekyll site structure to serve as the base for all documentation.

**Tech Stack:** Jekyll 4.x (GitHub Pages native static site generator)

**Architecture:**
- Uses Kramdown for markdown processing
- Rouge for syntax highlighting
- SEO and sitemap plugins for discoverability
- Clean layout structure with header/footer includes

**Why this approach:**
- Jekyll is GitHub Pages native (zero config deployment)
- Component-based includes allow reuse across pages
- Collections enable flexible content organization
acceptance_criteria: Jekyll site builds locally with 'bundle exec jekyll serve' and serves at http://localhost:4000; basic navigation works between pages; landing page displays correctly

title: Create custom code_file plugin
description:
# Create custom code_file plugin

Implement custom Liquid tag to embed source files in markdown.

## File to create

**`docs/_plugins/code_file.rb`:**
```ruby
module Jekyll
  class CodeFile < Liquid::Tag
    def initialize(tag_name, markup, tokens)
      super
      @path = markup.strip
    end

    def render(context)
      site = context.registers[:site]
      file_path = File.join(site.source, @path)
      if File.exist?(file_path)
        contents = File.read(file_path)
        syntax = file_path.split('.').last
        # Map extensions to syntax highlighter names
        syntax_map = {
          'py' => 'python',
          'go' => 'go',
          'java' => 'java',
          'ts' => 'typescript',
          'cs' => 'csharp',
          'rb' => 'ruby',
          'js' => 'javascript'
        }
        syntax = syntax_map[syntax] || syntax
        "```#{syntax}\n#{contents}\n```"
      else
        "_Error: File not found: #{@path}_"
      end
    end
  end
end

Liquid::Template.register_tag('code_file', Jekyll::CodeFile)
```

## Usage in markdown

```markdown
{% code_file examples/checkout-python/server.py %}
```

## Verification

- Using `{% code_file path/to/file.py %}` in markdown embeds file contents with syntax highlighting
- Missing files show helpful error message
- Jekyll builds without errors
design:
## Design Context

**Goal:** Enable embedding working source code directly into documentation.

**Why this approach:**
- Code lives as runnable source files, not copy-pasted in markdown
- Tests validate code works, preventing documentation rot
- Single source of truth for examples
- Changes to examples automatically reflected in docs

**Architecture:** Custom Jekyll plugin reads files at build time and embeds them with proper syntax highlighting.
acceptance_criteria: Using '{% code_file path/to/file.py %}' in markdown embeds file contents with syntax highlighting; missing files show helpful error message

title: GitHub Actions Binary Releases
description: Build and publish pre-built binaries for linux-amd64, linux-arm64, darwin-amd64, darwin-arm64, and windows-amd64 using GitHub Actions. Enable the "Download Pre-built Binary" installation method by automating releases on version tags.

title: Create build-binaries.yml workflow file
description:
Create the GitHub Actions workflow file `.github/workflows/build-binaries.yml` with the following structure:

## Triggers

```yaml
on:
  push:
    tags: ['v*']
  release:
    types: [published]
```

## Job: build (matrix)

Runs on `ubuntu-latest` with strategy matrix for 5 targets.

### Steps

1. **Checkout code**
   ```yaml
   - name: Checkout code
     uses: actions/checkout@v4
   ```

2. **Set up Go 1.21+**
   ```yaml
   - name: Set up Go
     uses: actions/setup-go@v5
     with:
       go-version: '1.21'
   ```

3. **Set up Node.js** (for web UI build)
   ```yaml
   - name: Set up Node.js
     uses: actions/setup-node@v4
     with:
       node-version: '20'
   ```

4. **Build web UI**
   ```yaml
   - name: Build web UI
     working-directory: pkg/webui
     run: |
       npm install
       npm run build
   ```

5. **Build binary for target platform**
   ```yaml
   - name: Build binary
     env:
       GOOS: ${{ matrix.goos }}
       GOARCH: ${{ matrix.goarch }}
     run: |
       mkdir -p target
       go build -o target/barrister-${{ matrix.binary_name }} cmd/barrister/barrister.go
   ```

6. **Upload artifact**
   ```yaml
   - name: Upload artifact
     uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
     with:
       name: barrister-${{ matrix.binary_name }}
       path: target/barrister-${{ matrix.binary_name }}
   ```

### Matrix configuration

```yaml
strategy:
  fail-fast: false
  matrix:
    include:
      - binary_name: linux-amd64
        goos: linux
        goarch: amd64
      - binary_name: linux-arm64
        goos: linux
        goarch: arm64
      - binary_name: darwin-amd64
        goos: darwin
        goarch: amd64
      - binary_name: darwin-arm64
        goos: darwin
        goarch: arm64
      - binary_name: windows-amd64
        goos: windows
        goarch: amd64
```

## Job: assemble

Depends on `build` job. Runs on `ubuntu-latest`.

### Steps

1. **Download all build artifacts**
   ```yaml
   - name: Download build artifacts
     uses: actions/download-artifact@v4
     with:
       path: release
       merge-multiple: true
   ```

2. **Compute checksums**
   ```yaml
   - name: Compute checksums
     working-directory: release
     run: |
       sha256sum barrister-* > barrister_checksums.txt
       cat barrister_checksums.txt
   ```

3. **Create release**
   ```yaml
   - name: Create Release
     uses: softprops/action-gh-release@v2
     with:
       files: release/*
       draft: true
       generate_release_notes: true
     env:
       GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
   ```

## Full workflow file

Create `.github/workflows/build-binaries.yml` with all the above combined.

## Testing

1. Push a test tag: `git tag v0.1.0-test && git push origin v0.1.0-test`
2. Verify workflow runs in Actions tab
3. Verify draft release is created with 5 binaries + checksums
4. Delete test tag and draft release after verification
design:
## Architecture Context

This workflow enables Method 2 (Download Pre-built Binary) in the installation documentation. It builds cross-platform binaries and uploads them to GitHub Releases.

## Tech Stack

- GitHub Actions (CI/CD)
- Go 1.21+ (language)
- Node.js 20 (web UI build)
- softprops/action-gh-release@v2 (release management)

## Design Decisions

1. **Matrix build strategy**: Single workflow with matrix eliminates code duplication and ensures consistent build steps across all platforms.

2. **Draft release on tag push**: Creates a draft release so maintainers can review before publishing. Prevents accidental releases.

3. **SHA256 checksums file**: `barrister_checksums.txt` allows users to verify binary integrity after download.

4. **Separate build and assemble jobs**: Build runs in parallel for all platforms; assemble waits for all to complete. This is more efficient than sequential builds.

## Data Flow

```
git push v1.0.0
    ↓
GitHub Actions triggered
    ↓
Matrix job spawns 5 parallel builds
    ↓
Each build: checkout → setup Go/Node → build web UI → compile binary → upload artifact
    ↓
assemble job downloads all artifacts
    ↓
Compute SHA256 checksums
    ↓
softprops/action-gh-release creates draft release with artifacts
    ↓
Maintainer publishes release
    ↓
Users download from /releases/latest/download/
```
acceptance_criteria: Workflow file created at .github/workflows/build-binaries.yml; Triggers on v* tags and release published; Builds 5 platform targets; Computes and uploads SHA256 checksums; Creates draft release with artifacts
close_reason: Implemented and verified: GitHub Actions workflow created at .github/workflows/build-binaries.yml with 5 platform builds, SHA256 checksums, and draft release creation
